docs.lead_paragraph: The successful battle for gay marriage legislation in New York State involved the debut of an intriguing new way to apply social media to social change: Friendfactor.  While the precise role it played in the law’s passage is unclear, Friendfactor offered  a new model for online organizing that could become very useful in similar rights campaigns.

headline.main: On Gay Rights, Moving Real-Life Friends to Action

docs.abstract: How one Web site capitalized on the bonds among friends to mobilize people in New York’s gay marriage campaign.
docs.snippet: How one Web site capitalized on the bonds among friends to mobilize people in New York’s gay marriage campaign.

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline.main: Thursday Reading: Measles Cases Spike as Unvaccinated Travelers Return Home

docs.abstract: Measles cases jump as unvaccinated travelers return home, surgically implanted bombs are latest air travel worry, a $100 weekend in Istanbul and other consumer focused news from The New York Times.
docs.snippet: Measles cases jump as unvaccinated travelers return home, surgically implanted bombs are latest air travel worry, a $100 weekend in Istanbul and other consumer focused news from The New York Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the nearly year and a half since Congress passed the health care overhaul, one of the main purposes of the bill — to provide health insurance to people who lack it — has often been lost in the debate. Instead, supporters and opponents of the bill have argued over whether the bill is constitutional, and they’ve argued over whether the bill will cut medical costs more or less than the Congressional Budget Office projects.
docs.abstract: A study by some of the country’s top health economists aims to estimate the effects of not having health insurance — and the effects are large.
docs.snippet: A study by some of the country’s top health economists aims to estimate the effects of not having health insurance — and the effects are large.

docs.lead_paragraph: The study adds to a long-running debate on Medicaid in a climate of cutbacks across the nation.

docs.lead_paragraph: A few years back, a spate of news reports and medical journal articles reporting that doctors were refusing to accept Medicare patients caught the attention of Dr. Tara Bishop, an internist and assistant professor of public health at Weill Cornell Medical College in New York. The articles, including one in The New York Times, blamed low reimbursement rates and burdensome paperwork requirements.
docs.abstract: A new study suggests that the vast majority of patients with Medicare have little trouble finding doctors.
docs.snippet: A new study suggests that the vast majority of patients with Medicare have little trouble finding doctors.
